source.raw_text:
The Sandbag March is a dynamic exercise that builds functional strength, targeting your legs (quads, glutes, hamstrings), core (abs, obliques, lower back) for stability, and upper back/shoulders to maintain posture, working through the locomotion/marching movement pattern to improve balance, coordination, and endurance, mimicking real-world movement. It's excellent for training your body to move as an integrated system, unlike static exercises. [1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6]  
Muscles Worked 

• Primary Movers (Legs): Glutes, Quadriceps, Hamstrings, Hip Flexors. 
• Core (Stabilizers): Abdominals, Obliques, Erector Spinae (lower back). 
• Upper Body (Stabilizers): Upper Back (Rhomboids, Traps), Rear Deltoids, Lats (to keep the bag tight). [1, 2, 3, 7, 8]  

Movement Patterns & Benefits 

• Locomotion: It's a fundamental walking pattern, enhancing balance and preventing shuffling. 
• Dynamic Stability: The unstable nature of the sandbag forces deep core engagement to prevent swaying, improving anti-rotation and anti-extension. 
• Single-Leg Strength: It trains single-leg stability and coordination, crucial for walking, running, and reducing fall risk. 
• Posterior Chain Activation: Works the glutes and hamstrings together, vital for power and stability. 
• Full-Body Integration: Connects upper body tension (pulling handles apart) with lower body movement, building resilient, connected strength. [2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 8, 9]  

How It Works (Bear Hug Carry Example) 

1. Grab the Sandbag: Bear-hug it tightly to your chest for maximum core/upper back engagement. 
2. March: Lift one knee high (engaging hip flexors) while keeping your torso tall and stable. 
3. Maintain Tension: "Pull" the handles apart to keep the upper back engaged and prevent rounding. 
4. Coordinate: Your core and glutes work together to stabilize your pelvis and body as you move through single-leg stances. [2, 4, 7, 8]
